channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Ukraine to seek European integration
item.description: Ukraine's new interim President Oleksandr Turchynov says Ukraine will focus on closer ties with Europe, a day after tumultuous events in Kiev.

item.title: North Sea oil tops cabinet agendas
item.description: Ministers from both the UK and Scottish governments are in north-east Scotland to set out plans for the future of the North Sea oil and gas industry.

item.title: Oldest Holocaust survivor dies
item.description: The oldest known survivor of the Nazi Holocaust, Alice Herz-Sommer, dies in London at the age of 110.

item.title: Syria al-Qaeda-linked rebel killed
item.description: A Syrian militant leader linked to al-Qaeda is killed in a suicide attack in Aleppo, amid a bitter power struggle between rebel factions.

item.title: Russia on top as 2014 Games end
item.description: Hosts Russia finish top of the medal table and Britain equal their best performance as Sochi 2014 comes to an end.

item.title: Morsi 'leaked secrets to Iran'
item.description: Egyptian prosecutors have accused ousted President Mohammed Morsi of leaking state secrets to Iran's Revolutionary Guards.

item.title: Afghan troops die in Taliban attack
item.description: Taliban fighters kill 21 Afghan soldiers in an attack on a checkpoint in Kunar province close to Afghanistan's border with Pakistan.

item.title: Centrica scaremongering, says Labour
item.description: Labour accuses British Gas owner Centrica of scaremongering over the party's planned energy price freeze.

item.title: Tax evaders targeted in ad campaign
item.description: The government launches an advertising campaign targeting people who have been evading taxes by holding money in offshore accounts.

item.title: First openly gay player in the NBA
item.description: Jason Collins has become the first openly gay basketball player to sign for a team in America's NBA.

item.title: Sam Smith scores UK chart number one
item.description: Singer Sam Smith scores his first solo number one in the UK singles chart with his latest track, Money On My Mind.

item.title: Ukraine and pit bulls in papers
item.description: The political crisis in Ukraine continues to concern the papers and there are other worries about pensions and pit bull terriers.

item.title: VIDEO: Team GB perform Pharrell's 'Happy'
item.description: Team GB's Winter Olympians perform 'Happy' by Pharrell Williams as BBC Sport looks back at their greatest moments from Sochi 2014.

item.title: Samsung tries again with new watches
item.description: Samsung has shown off the Gear 2, its second attempt at releasing a smartwatch that has mass appeal with consumers.

item.title: GB winter sports to get funding boost
item.description: National funding body UK Sport is set to increase financial support for British winter sports following a successful Sochi Games.

item.title: Sprinter Sacre to miss Cheltenham
item.description: Champion Chase favourite Sprinter Sacre will miss the Cheltenham Festival next month, trainer Nicky Henderson confirms.

item.title: Liverpool 4-3 Swansea City
item.description: Jordan Henderson and Daniel Sturridge both score twice as Liverpool beat Swansea in a pulsating encounter at Anfield.

item.title: Norwich City 1 - 0 Tottenham Hotspur
item.description: Robert Snodgrass scores the only goal as Norwich beat fifth-placed Tottenham to ease their relegation fears.

item.title: Jonathan Davies's Six Nations Team of the Week
item.description: Who makes BBC expert Jonathan Davies's Team of the Week after the third round of the Six Nations?

item.title: Budget 'must focus on youth jobless'
item.description: Chancellor George Osborne must include measures in the March Budget to address youth unemployment and training, the British Chambers of Commerce says.

item.title: VIDEO: Explaining the deficit... with sweets
item.description: BBC chief economics correspondent Hugh Pym explains the terminology of government debt with the aid of some coloured sweets.

item.title: Many dangers in Ukraine, warns Hague
item.description: Unrest in Ukraine poses "many dangers", the UK's foreign secretary says as he prepares for talks with the Russian foreign minister.

item.title: VIDEO: Hague: 'Still many dangers' in Ukraine
item.description: The UK foreign secretary has said "there are still many dangers" facing Ukraine and the position of the opposition is "complex".

item.title: NHS trusts with deficits rise to 39
item.description: A study of NHS foundation trusts in England finds the number of those in financial trouble has nearly doubled in a year from 21 to 39.

item.title: VIDEO: Video goggles for hospital patients
item.description: Some patients at Harrogate Hospital are being given video goggles to wear during operations, while under local anaesthetic.

item.title: New talks over university pay claim
item.description: Fresh talks are set to be held between academics unions and university employers amid a row over pay.

item.title: AUDIO: Remarking exams is 'tactical move'
item.description: Ofqual has accused schools of tactically appealing against exam results to try to boost students' grades.

item.title: '$25 smartphone' coming from Mozilla
item.description: A prototype smartphone that costs $25 and is designed to appeal to people in developing countries is shown off by Mozilla at the Mobile World Congress.

item.title: VIDEO: 'More beautiful' selfies feature
item.description: Huawei's latest smartphone promises better selfies - the BBC's Mark Gregory tried it out.

item.title: Tree loss mapped in 'near real time'
item.description: A new global monitoring system has been launched that promises "near real time" information on deforestation around the world.

item.title: VIDEO: Earthquake hits south west Britain
item.description: An earthquake has been felt in areas of south west Britain this afternoon - the British Geological Society has confirmed. No damage has been reported so far

item.title: Harry Potter stars win stage awards
item.description: Harry Potter stars Daniel Radcliffe and Rupert Grint both win acting prizes at the WhatsOnStage awards.

item.title: VIDEO: Recreating zero gravity on film
item.description: Gravity's director Alfonso Cuaron and effects house Framestore on the painstaking process of creating the film's award-winning special effects.

item.title: Should the English have a say on Scottish independence?
item.description: Should the English also have a right to decide on Scottish independence, asks Roger Scruton.

item.title: The urban hyenas that attack rough sleepers
item.description: Urban hyenas are becoming a dangerous problem in the Ethiopian capital, Addis Ababa writes Martin Fletcher.

item.title: Pensioner killer found dead in jail
item.description: A murderer who spent 12 years denying he had killed a pensioner before admitting his guilt is found dead in prison.

item.title: Murderer absconds on town visit
item.description: A man convicted of murdering an 85-year-old man in 1996 absconds while on a day release from prison in Rochdale.

item.title: New Lanark tenement gets lotto cash
item.description: A row of tenements used by mill workers in the conservation village of New Lanark is to be restored after being awarded Heritage Lottery Fund cash.

item.title: Glasgow to host Commonwealth Flotilla
item.description: A Commonwealth flotilla of 250 craft will sail from Greenock's James Watt Dock to Glasgow's Pacific Quay in late July.

item.title: Arrests after four men attacked
item.description: A 24-year-old man is in a critical condition in hospital after he and three other men were assaulted in north Belfast.

item.title: NI man involved in Eta weapons move
item.description: A former senior government official from Northern Ireland is among a six-member commission that claims to have witnessed arms decommissioning by the Basque separatist group, Eta.

item.title: Prayers said for baby Eliza-Mae
item.description: Special prayers are said for six-day-old baby Eliza-Mae Mullane, who died at Pontyberem where her family's pet dog was later seized by police.

item.title: Rain and wind alert remains in place
item.description: Heavy rain and strong winds are set to continue in parts of north Wales into Monday, say forecasters.

item.title: Algeria's president to seek new term
item.description: The Algerian president, who has not publicly addressed the country for nearly three years, will run for re-election, his office says.

item.title: Mugabe marks his 90th birthday
item.description: Thousands of Zimbabweans attend an official 90th birthday celebration for President Robert Mugabe.

item.title: Deadly attacks hit rallies in Thailand
item.description: A bomb kills two people near a protest site in a busy shopping district of Bangkok, hours after a deadly gun attack on a rally in eastern Thailand.

item.title: Huawei launches 'hybrid' smartband
item.description: Chinese electronics giant Huawei unveiled five new products at Mobile World Congress, including what it called the "world's first hybrid smart band".

item.title: Eta monitors 'working for peace'
item.description: Monitors trying to secure the disarmament of Eta insist their goal is peace, after facing questions by Spanish judges over a meeting with militants.

item.title: Scotland given tough Euro 2016 task
item.description: Scotland and the Republic of Ireland are drawn in the same qualifying group for Euro 2016, while England face Switzerland.

item.title: Mexico's 'Shorty' Guzman arrested
item.description: One of the world's most wanted drug barons, Joaquin "Shorty" Guzman, is arrested in a joint US-Mexican operation in Mexico's Sinaloa state.

item.title: Violent clashes at Venezuela march
item.description: Venezuelan police and anti-government activists clash in Caracas, as the opposition continues a campaign of protests against President Maduro.

item.title: Israel police shoot dead US killer
item.description: Israeli special forces shoot dead an American-Israeli prisoner - jailed for a brutal murder in the US - after he opened fire on prison guards.

item.title: Libya Islamist killed in plane crash
item.description: A former Islamist fighter who joined Libya's government is among 11 people killed when a Libyan military plane crashes in Tunisia, officials say.

item.title: Netflix signs Comcast streaming deal
item.description: Netflix agrees a deal with Comcast, the biggest internet service provider in the US, that will see its videos streamed faster and more smoothly.

item.title: Protests at Arizona 'anti-gay' bill
item.description: Protests are held against the Arizona legislature's first-in-the-nation passage of a bill allowing business owners to refuse service to gay people.

item.title: Week in pictures: 15-21 February 2014
item.description: News from around the world: 15-21 Feb

item.title: Day in pictures: 20 February 2014
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 20 February

item.title: Queen's Baton Relay: Africa
item.description: African leg of the Queen's Baton Relay

item.title: Your pictures: Rainfall
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme of rainfall.

item.title: In pictures: Brit Awards 2014
item.description: Britain's biggest music awards ceremony

item.title: Day in pictures: 19 February 2014
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 19 February

item.title: In pictures: Ukraine clashes
item.description: Further violence in Kiev

item.title: In pictures: Lives of Syrian refugees in a Bulgarian camp
item.description: Lives of Syrians in a European refugee centre

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: MPs discuss a report on cancer priorities for the National Health Service.

item.title: VIDEO: China pandas arrive in Belgium
item.description: Two giant pandas have been flown into Belgium on a 15-year loan from China's Sichuan region.

item.title: VIDEO: Funniest moments of Sochi 2014
item.description: BBC Sport looks back at some of the funniest moments from Sochi 2014, from the outrageous trousers of Norway's curlers to the Russian police choir's take on Daft Punk.

item.title: VIDEO: Last of Trapp Family Singers dies
item.description: The last surviving member of the Trapp Family Singers, whose story inspired the musical and Oscar-winning film The Sound of Music, has died aged 99.

item.title: VIDEO: Eta mediators quizzed in court
item.description: International mediators are questioned at Spain's High Court after helping with the partial disarmament of Basque militant group Eta.

item.title: VIDEO: Rainforest space mystery solved
item.description: Experts from Swansea University to fix the problem of satellites producing an optical illusion on the Amazon rainforest.

item.title: VIDEO: Mugabe celebrates 90th birthday
item.description: Thousands of Zimbabweans have attended an official 90th birthday celebration for President Robert Mugabe.

item.title: VIDEO: Rally driver honoured in home city
item.description: Rally champion Paddy Hopkirk leads a cavalcade of cars through Belfast as part of a series of events marking the 50th anniversary of his 1964 Monte Carlo victory.

item.title: VIDEO: Violent clashes at Venezuela protest
item.description: Venezuelan police and anti-government activists clash in Caracas, as the opposition continues a campaign of protests against President Maduro.

item.title: Hotel where warfare changed forever
item.description: How the tank’s invention was secretly plotted in a Lincoln hotel

item.title: Seven months pregnant and working in the fields
item.description: The women who work in the fields until the day they give birth

item.title: The music of the Persian underground
item.description: Iranian musicians in exile because their songs are banned

item.title: Was the DC-10 unfairly maligned?
item.description: Was the DC-10's reputation as a 'death trap' unfair?

item.title: Are artists taking over the film world?
item.description: A new breed of successful film-makers

item.title: How do we really make decisions?
item.description: The battle waged every time you make a decision

item.title: India's child cotton pickers at risk
item.description: How do you protect India's child pickers?

item.title: Could there be a third world war?
item.description: Could there ever be another world war, asks John Simpson?

item.title: When will the world economy recover?
item.description: When will the global and UK economies recover?
